title.children: Gabba redevelopment options revealed, new East Brisbane State School location announced

image.altText: A headshot of Belinda

items.synopsis: Professional garbologist Bel has so little landfill waste she's ditched her red bin. Here's how she did it.

title.children: Bel has reduced her household waste to just 4kg a year. This is how she ditched her red bin

image.altText: A red car is just showing out of soil and trees which have slipped off a hill on a beach

items.synopsis: A major landslip has buried a car and damaged another at a popular tourist destination. Residents say it is the biggest slip they have seen in the region.

title.children: Drivers 'very lucky' not to be hurt in Rainbow Beach landslip

image.altText: a close up of a curved dagger, known as a Kirpan, hanging from the belt of a robe

items.synopsis: The court ruling overturns an earlier decision that dismissed a claim from an Australian Sikh woman arguing the ban essentially prevented Sikhs from entering school grounds, which is against the Racial Discrimination Act.

title.children: A Queensland court just allowed some people to carry knives in schools. Here's why

image.altText: Hawthorn Hawks signage at the clubs headquarters in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: The author of the Hawthorn Football Club cultural safety review and former CEO of the Murray Valley Aboriginal Cooperative has been charged as part of a Victoria Police investigation into alleged financial mismanagement.

title.children: Hawthorn Football Club cultural safety review author Phil Egan charged with fraud-related offences

image.altText: A vendor sits near a board depicting surveillance cameras during Security China 2023 in Beijing.

title.children: US expresses 'great concern' over China's call to mobilise entire nation in counterespionage

items.synopsis: The pelvic floor is something most people don't talk about and many don't even know about. Here's why it's important and how to look after yours.

image.altText: A young white woman carefully lifting a toddler up at a playground

items.synopsis: New research suggests the number of Australian women who sustain life-altering injuries to their pelvic floor after birth is far higher than acknowledged.

title.children: Pelvic floor physio before and after childbirth could reduce Australia's 'hidden epidemic'

image.altText: a man with his arms folded looks at the camera while standing in his kitchen

items.synopsis: Tristan Hockings claims his hearing problems "significantly deteriorated" after the alleged assault in January 2019, forcing him to leave his job as a nurse.

title.children: Tristan went on a date that ended in a police raid. Now he's suing police for alleged assault

image.altText: Sydney skyline at night.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest companies are detailing the impact cost-of-living pressures and high interest rates have had on their bottom line. Analysts say the results will give an early warning sign as to where the economy is heading.

title.children: 'Consumer spending has really fallen off a cliff': Corporate reporting season offers a window on the economy's future

image.altText: Colourful helium balloons with streamers attached floating under a ceiling

items.synopsis: A range of single-use plastics will be banned from September 1 as the Queensland government weighs up if it will go ahead with even more bans next year.

title.children: Balloon releases banned as Queensland launches plastics hit list

image.altText: Inside a cinder block cell with a chair, a light, unplastered wall, a fan and concreate ground. Very confined

items.synopsis: The FBI is looking for more potential victims after a woman kidnapped and locked in a makeshift cell by a man posing as an undercover police officer managed to escape.

title.children: US woman escapes after being kidnapped, locked up in homemade cell

image.altText: Monkeypox view under the microscope

items.synopsis: Victoria's health department says two cases of mpox have been recorded in the state. They are first known cases in Victoria since November 2022.

title.children: Victoria records first locally acquired mpox cases since November

image.altText: An image of Sydney's CBD, with people walking, faces not visible, carrying shopping bags.

items.synopsis: A sharp dip in retail sales volumes offers a big hint as to why there was no interest rate hike from the RBA this week. Follow our live blog.

title.children: Retail sales figures help explain RBA rate hike pause

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Those underwhelming retail figures my colleague Michael Janda has been posting about have seen the Australian dollar take another hit. At midday it was about 65.45 US cents, but it's now about 65.31 US cents. It also lost more than a per cent last night. A lot of it has to do with what the market thinks about the RBA's interest rate decision (and future moves or otherwise). Across the ditch in New Zealand, their dollar is also lower against the greenback.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dollar down

children.content: Those underwhelming retail figures my colleague
has been posting about have seen the Australian dollar take another hit.
At midday it was about 65.45 US cents, but it's now about 65.31 US cents.
It also lost more than a per cent last night.
A lot of it has to do with what the market thinks about the RBA's interest rate decision (and future moves or otherwise).
Across the ditch in New Zealand, their dollar is also lower against the greenback.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Downer EDI announced it expects to report a statutory net loss after tax of about $386 million for the 2023 financial year. The company will write off almost $550 million when it reports its full-year results to the market next week. The impairment comes from increased debt costs and "tightening market conditions" for its cleaning and maintenance business Spotless, which caters to the defence sector. Downer EDI lowered its forecasts after lawsuits were filed alleging breaches of disclosures regarding a maintenance contract and the Sydney-based company revealed accounting irregularities in December. "Downer is undergoing a period of significant and necessary organisational change. Against this backdrop, we have delivered underlying earnings in line with what was previously communicated," CEO Peter Tompkins said in a statement. Downer EDI posted its biggest single-day loss in six months, falling nearly 6 per cent, but has recovered some of that fall in mid-afternoon trade to sit a bit over 2 per cent below yesterday's closing figure.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Downer EDI a downer on the market today

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a bit of movement on the ASX today among some companies in the battery metals space. Australian Strategic Materials (ASM), which owns deposits in New South Wales (though is yet to mine anything and sources its rare earths ore from other miners in Asia), has signed a deal with USA Rare Earth. ASM owns a rare earths processing plant in South Korea — that arm of the business has signed a five-year deal with the US company to supply neodymium iron boron alloy from 2024. Neodymium is used to make permanent magnets for things like medical imaging machines, engines and communications technology. It's shares are up more than 5 per cent. Liontown Resources, which mines lithium (another critical component in batteries) in the Goldfields region of WA, announced today it will export lithium direct shipping ore (DSO) (the least refined product) before it exports its first concentrate (ore that's been partly refined) as way to raise some cash. Liontown has so far stockpiled 70,000 tonnes of DSO and expects to sell up to 300,000 tonnes, likely starting by the end of this calendar year. Liontown's m anaging director and CEO, Tony Ottaviano, said: "Progressing with the production of DSO not only provides early revenue potential, but also enables us to de-risk the project by field testing our ore sorting and logistics solutions on a smaller scale ahead of first concentrate production mid-2024." Liontown shares are up 0.2 per cent .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Battery Metals in demand

image.altText: Somalia's Nasra Abukar crosses the line last in the women's 100 metres at the FISU World University Games in Chengdu, China.

items.synopsis: Somalia's university union says it has not sent any runners to the World University Games in China, but Nasra Abukar still appeared in the 100m heats, running an embarrassingly slow race.

title.children: Somalian's glacial 100m race prompts apology from country's sports minister

image.altText: Christopher Walsh sits at a computer screen which shows web browser with an NT Independent article loaded.

items.synopsis: The NT Independent is the subject of a prolonged NT government ban, which Chief Minister Natasha Fyles has defended by claiming it publishes "misinformation".

image.altText: Ollie Robinson, Stuart Broad, Ben Stokes and Jimmy Anderson talk during an Ashes Test.

image.altText: A man smiles at the camera

image.altText: Paul McCartney raises his arms on stage

title.children: 'I'm singing with my old buddy again': Paul McCartney on how AI is bringing John Lennon back on stage
